items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: With New Laws, a Focus on Nurturing the City’s Native Plants
items.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law on Monday three “green” bills, including measures on the city’s planting policy and the creation of a renewable energy portal.

items.title: Recalling Killing That Led Officers to Reclaim the City
items.abstract: More than a hundred officers gathered for the anniversary of the killing of Officer Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old rookie shot and killed in his car one morning in 1988.

items.title: Mexican Fare With Flair in Kansas City, Mo.
items.abstract: Port Fonda attracts a dedicated following, even though the chef warns it’s “not a place that everybody should even like.”

items.title: A Wave of Public Art for New York City
items.abstract: From Imran Quereshi on the Met roof to Tony Smith in Bryant Park, the sculpture season will be in full swing by May.

items.title: New York City and Correction Officers Reach Tentative Contract Deal
items.abstract: If approved, the contract would include an 11 percent raise over seven years and measures that would enable more efficient prosecution of inmates who assault officers at Rikers Island.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: How Cynthia Rowley, Fashion Designer, Spends Her Sundays
items.abstract: Ms. Rowley unwinds by doing “extreme activities” — working out, go-kart racing, sledding — with her husband and their two daughters.

items.title: National World War I Memorial Proposal Is Unveiled
items.abstract: A plan for a privately funded war memorial would create a raised lawn with a sculpture on a 1.8 acre site near the White House, not part of the National Mall.

items.title: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
items.abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which debuts on Tuesday, is the 10th ballet Mr. Peck has choreographed for the company he joined in 2007.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: His Art, Their Ideas: Did Robert Indiana Lose Control of His Work?
items.abstract: Private text messages entered as evidence in a legal dispute raise new questions about whether the artist fully designed his final works.

items.title: We Need a National Rural Broadband Plan
items.abstract: The government has given a lot of money to major telecommunications companies without much regulatory accountability.

items.title: New York City Public Schools Should Be Evaluated Based on Diversity, Not Just Tests, Panel Says
items.abstract: A new report suggests the city enact sweeping measures to address entrenched segregation in education.

items.title: New York City’s Subway Isn’t Run by the Mayor. Should It Be?
items.abstract: Corey Johnson, the City Council speaker, has a new proposal to allow the city to take control of the subway.

items.title: Lemon Pepper Makes Everything Better — Especially Wings
items.abstract: Zesty, buttery lemon-pepper wings are Atlanta’s soul. But you can use the seasoning on just about anything.

items.title: India’s budget focuses on roads, but critics see need for more jobs.
items.abstract: Narendra Modi’s plan calls for a big increase in infrastructure spending. Some say more must be done to create jobs for the country’s young work force.

items.title: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: A ‘Village in the City’
items.abstract: With its desirable 19th-century rowhouses and convenient subway access, the neighborhood is both homey and worldly.

items.title: A Classic Parisian Apartment Filled With Modern Design
items.abstract: By placing contemporary pieces amid original features, the architect Sophie Dries has created a space that privileges experimentation.

items.title: New York City Plans to Stop Homeless People From Sheltering in Subway
items.abstract: The plan calls for stricter enforcement of transit system rules and more mental-health services and housing options for those being cleared from stations and trains.
